subject: Data
title: Google Bigtable: When SQL Wasn't Enough
description: A quick win: understand Google Bigtable: When SQL Wasn't Enough.

hook.text: Google needed to store the entire internet's index. No relational database on Earth could handle it.

buildup.text: In 2006, Google published a paper describing Bigtable â€” a distributed storage system that abandoned SQL entirely.

discovery.text: Bigtable stored data in wide, sparse columns across thousands of cheap servers rather than expensive single machines.

twist.text: Google didn't sell Bigtable. But the paper inspired open-source clones like HBase that powered the NoSQL revolution.

climax.text: Bigtable proved that at massive scale, the rules of traditional databases had to be rewritten from scratch.

punchline.text: Google's search engine was too big for databases. So they invented a new kind.

quiz.question: What did Google's Bigtable paper inspire?
options: The NoSQL movement and open-source clones like HBase
